displaytitle: War Views: This picture is a good view of the covered ways inside the Rebel Fort Mahone, called by the soldiers, "Fort Damnation"
creditline: Gift of David B. Long in honor of Joe Cavallaro
markings:
Stamped on left: Photographic History

Stamped on right: The War for the Union

Stamped below: Entered according to Act of Congress in the year 1865 by E. & H.T. Anthony & Co. in the Clerk's Office of the Distric Court of the U.S. for the So. District of New York.

Typed on paper adhered to verso: WAR VIEWS. | This Picture is a good view of the covered ways inside the Rebel Fort Mahone, | called by the soldiers "Fort Damnation." The Union soldiers had to charge up and down the obstructions, | In the foreground centre is a dead rebel soldier sticking out through the debris, and further on lies | another Confederate soldier. | No. 3183 | Copyright secured. | Published by E. & H.T. Anthony & Co., | American and Foreign Stereoscopic Emporium, 501 Broadway, New-York.

titles.title: War Views: This picture is a good view of the covered ways inside the Rebel Fort Mahone, called by the soldiers, "Fort Damnation"

makers.displaymaker: Published by E. and H. T. Anthony, active 1852–1901, New York

texts.textentryhtml:
Undeterred by dangerous circumstances and motivated by commercial success, Thomas C. Roche was among the few battlefield photographers to remain near the Petersburg, Virginia, front during the last days of the Civil War, producing one of the most extensive series of battlefield views. Many of his photographs are stereographs, a format that places two images taken at slightly different angles side by side on a single card. When viewed through a binocular device called a stereoscope, the two images coalesce into one, producing an illusion of three-dimensionality. Widely distributed to convey narratives related to the recent war, these stereographs serve as examples of photography’s role as a tool of mass communication.

This image shows the route into the trenches and the body of a Confederate soldier. Further in the distance is another soldier, his body barely visible. Roche may have rearranged the body in the foreground to mimic the lines of the wooden barricade in the lower right corner, thus enhancing the scene’s sense of depth. This arrangement would help this photograph seem to come alive in three dimensions when placed in a stereo viewer, a binocular device that would cause the two images on the card, taken at slightly different angles, to coalesce into a single frame. The position of the soldier’s body obscures his face from the viewer, and his anonymity may serve as a symbol for the countless lives that perished in the war.
Purchased by David B. Long; given to the Princeton University Art Museum, 2018.

bibliography.boilertext: "Acquisitions of the Princeton University Art Museum 2018," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 77/78 (2017-18)
